notes:
1. Definition

Torsional deformation is the twisting of a member when it is subjected to a torque (a moment acting about its longitudinal axis). The deformation is quantified by the angle of twist ($\phi$).

2. Formula for Angle of Twist

For a circular shaft of constant cross-section subjected to a torque $T$, the angle of twist is given by:

$$ \phi = \frac{TL}{JG} $$
  • $\phi$: Angle of twist (in radians).
  • $T$: Applied torque.
  • $L$: Length of the shaft.
  • $J$: Polar moment of inertia of the cross-section.
  • $G$: Shear modulus of elasticity (or modulus of rigidity) of the material.

The polar moment of inertia for a solid circular shaft is $J = \frac{\pi}{2}r^4 = \frac{\pi}{32}d^4$. For a hollow circular shaft, $J = \frac{\pi}{2}(r_o^4 - r_i^4)$.

solvedExamples.question: A solid steel shaft with a diameter of 2 inches and a length of 50 inches is subjected to a torque of 10,000 in-lb. The shear modulus for steel is G = 11.5 × 10⁶ psi. What is the angle of twist in radians?
solvedExamples.explanation: First, calculate the polar moment of inertia, J. The diameter is d = 2 inches. $J = \frac{\pi}{32}d^4 = \frac{\pi}{32}(2)^4 = \frac{16\pi}{32} = 1.571 \text{ in}^4$. Now use the angle of twist formula: $\phi = \frac{TL}{JG} = \frac{(10,000 \text{ in-lb})(50 \text{ in})}{(1.571 \text{ in}^4)(11.5 \times 10^6 \text{ lb/in²})} = \frac{500,000}{18,066,500} \approx 0.0277$ rad.
